fr:title.text: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be a cloven fibration over B; in this case, we may use the cleaving of E to give a simple construction of the opposite fibration E^{\mathsf {op}}.

html:ol.html:li: A displayed object of E^{\mathsf {op}} over x\in B is given by an object of E over x.
Given {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{u}\in B, a displayed morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} in E^{\mathsf {op}} is given by a vertical map {f^{*}\bar {y}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{h}{\bar {x}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We adapt Bénabou’s construction as reported by Streicher. Our first construction works for an uncloven fibration, but it has the downside that it requires us to treat the collection of cartesian lifts as a set that can be quotiented, whereas our second construction avoids this by virtue of a cleaving. Up to equivalence, the two constructions coincide for a cloven fibration, which shows that our second construction is independent of the chosen cleaving.

fr:title.text: The opposite of an uncloven fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The opposite of an uncloven fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be fibered over B; we may define the opposite fibered category E^{\mathsf {op}} over B like so:

html:ol.html:li: An object of E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x} is given by an object of E_{x}.

html:li.html:p: Given {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y}\in B, a morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {y} in E^{\mathsf {op}} is given in terms of E by a cartesian map {\bar {y}_{x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {y}_{f}}{\bar {y}} together with a vertical map {\bar {y}_{x}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{h}{\bar {x}} as depicted below:

such that {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x} \leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}^{1}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} is identified with {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}^{2}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} when they agree up to the unique vertical isomorphism \bar {y}_{x}^{1}\cong \bar {y}_{x}^{2} induced by the universal property of cartesian maps in the sense that the following diagram commutes:

fr:title.text: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be a cloven fibration over B; in this case, we may use the cleaving of E to give a simple construction of the opposite fibration E^{\mathsf {op}}.

html:ol.html:li: A displayed object of E^{\mathsf {op}} over x\in B is given by an object of E over x.
Given {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{u}\in B, a displayed morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} in E^{\mathsf {op}} is given by a vertical map {f^{*}\bar {y}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{h}{\bar {x}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Going forward, we will not be sensitive to the difference between the two constructions of opposite fibrations.

fr:title.text: Cartesian maps in the opposite category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian maps in the opposite category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a simple characterization of cartesian maps in E^{\mathsf {op}}.
A morphism {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} is cartesian over {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y} if and only if the vertical leg of f is an isomorphism.

Suppose that {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}} is represented by a span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} in E in which the vertical leg \bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x} is an isomorphism. We must show that {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}} is cartesian in E^{\mathsf {op}}. We fix a morphism {\bar {w}}\xrightarrow [m;f]{\bar {h}}{\bar {y}}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} where {w}\xrightarrow {{m}}{x}, depicted below in terms of E^{\mathsf {op}}:
We must define the unique intervening map {\bar {w}}\xrightarrow [m]{}{\bar {x}} in E^{\mathsf {op}}. We first translate the above into the language of E by unfolding definitions:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <0/>{ west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, north/style = {<-}, south/style = double, height = 1.5cm, nw = \bar {w}, sw = w, se = w, ne = \bar {y}_{w}, north = \bar {h}, ne/style = pullback, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <1/>{ glue = west, glue target = 0/, east/style = lies over, height = 1.5cm, ne/style = pullback, se = x, ne = \bar {y}_{x}\cong \bar {x}, south = m, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <2/>{ glue = west, glue target = 1/, east/style = lies over, height = 1.5cm, se = y, ne = \bar {y}, south = f, north = \bar {f}, } \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The desired intervening map \bar {w}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {x}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} shakes out in the language of E to be a span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {w}\xleftarrow [1_{w}]{} \bar {y}_{w}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {x}\right \}\mathclose {}} in which the left-hand leg is vertical and the right-hand leg is cartesian over {w}\xrightarrow {{m}}{x}. But the left-hand span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {w}\xleftarrow [1_{w}]{}\bar {y}_{w}\to \bar {y}_{x}\cong \bar {x}\right \}\mathclose {}} in the diagram above is exactly what we need.
We leave the converse to the reader.

fr:title.text: Cartesian lifts in the opposite category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian lifts in the opposite category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The foregoing characterization of cartesian maps in E^{\mathsf {op}} immediately implies that E^{\mathsf {op}} is fibered over B.
The displayed category E^{\mathsf {op}} is a cartesian fibration.

Fixing \bar {y}\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{y} and f:x\to y\in B, we must exhibit a cartesian lift \bar {f} : \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y}\in E^{\mathsf {op}}. By the characterization it suffices to find any map over f whose vertical component is an isomorphism. Writing \bar {y}_{x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} for the cartesian lift of f in E, consider the map in E^{\mathsf {op}} presented by the following span in E:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <l/>{ nw = \bar {y}_{x}, ne = \bar {y}_{x}, sw = x, se = x, north/style = double, south/style = double, west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, ne/style = pullback, height = 1.5cm, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <r/>{ glue = west, glue target = l/, height = 1.5cm, east/style = lies over, ne = \bar {y}, se = y, south = f, } \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The construction of fibered opposite categories does appear quite involved, but it can be seen to be inevitable from the perspective of the fiber categories E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x}. Indeed, let u,v\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x} and fix a vertical map h : u \to v\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x}; by unfolding definitions, we see that the vertical map h : u \to v is uniquely determined by a morphism v\to u\in E_{x}.

A displayed morphism u\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{} v\in E^{\mathsf {op}} is determined by a span {\mathopen {}\left \{u\leftarrow v_{x} \to v\right \}\mathclose {}}\in E where the right-hand map is cartesian over 1_{x} : x\to x and the left-hand map is vertical, taken up to the identification of different cartesian lifts v_{x}\to x. A displayed morphism that is cartesian over the identity is an isomorphism; hence, displayed morphisms u\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{} v\in E^{\mathsf {op}} are equivalently determined by vertical maps v\to u \in E.

We adapt Bénabou’s construction as reported by Streicher. Our first construction works for an uncloven fibration, but it has the downside that it requires us to treat the collection of cartesian lifts as a set that can be quotiented, whereas our second construction avoids this by virtue of a cleaving. Up to equivalence, the two constructions coincide for a cloven fibration, which shows that our second construction is independent of the chosen cleaving.

fr:title.text: The opposite of an uncloven fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The opposite of an uncloven fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be fibered over B; we may define the opposite fibered category E^{\mathsf {op}} over B like so:

html:ol.html:li: An object of E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x} is given by an object of E_{x}.

html:li.html:p: Given {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y}\in B, a morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{} \bar {y} in E^{\mathsf {op}} is given in terms of E by a cartesian map {\bar {y}_{x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {y}_{f}}{\bar {y}} together with a vertical map {\bar {y}_{x}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{h}{\bar {x}} as depicted below:

such that {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x} \leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}^{1}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} is identified with {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}^{2}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} when they agree up to the unique vertical isomorphism \bar {y}_{x}^{1}\cong \bar {y}_{x}^{2} induced by the universal property of cartesian maps in the sense that the following diagram commutes:

fr:title.text: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The opposite of a cloven fibration

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let E be a cloven fibration over B; in this case, we may use the cleaving of E to give a simple construction of the opposite fibration E^{\mathsf {op}}.

html:ol.html:li: A displayed object of E^{\mathsf {op}} over x\in B is given by an object of E over x.
Given {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{u}\in B, a displayed morphism \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} in E^{\mathsf {op}} is given by a vertical map {f^{*}\bar {y}}\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{h}{\bar {x}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Going forward, we will not be sensitive to the difference between the two constructions of opposite fibrations.

fr:title.text: Cartesian maps in the opposite category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian maps in the opposite category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a simple characterization of cartesian maps in E^{\mathsf {op}}.
A morphism {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} is cartesian over {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y} if and only if the vertical leg of f is an isomorphism.

Suppose that {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}} is represented by a span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x}\to \bar {y}\right \}\mathclose {}} in E in which the vertical leg \bar {x}\leftarrow \bar {y}_{x} is an isomorphism. We must show that {\bar {x}}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{\bar {y}} is cartesian in E^{\mathsf {op}}. We fix a morphism {\bar {w}}\xrightarrow [m;f]{\bar {h}}{\bar {y}}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} where {w}\xrightarrow {{m}}{x}, depicted below in terms of E^{\mathsf {op}}:
We must define the unique intervening map {\bar {w}}\xrightarrow [m]{}{\bar {x}} in E^{\mathsf {op}}. We first translate the above into the language of E by unfolding definitions:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <0/>{ west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, north/style = {<-}, south/style = double, height = 1.5cm, nw = \bar {w}, sw = w, se = w, ne = \bar {y}_{w}, north = \bar {h}, ne/style = pullback, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <1/>{ glue = west, glue target = 0/, east/style = lies over, height = 1.5cm, ne/style = pullback, se = x, ne = \bar {y}_{x}\cong \bar {x}, south = m, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <2/>{ glue = west, glue target = 1/, east/style = lies over, height = 1.5cm, se = y, ne = \bar {y}, south = f, north = \bar {f}, } \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The desired intervening map \bar {w}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {x}\in E^{\mathsf {op}} shakes out in the language of E to be a span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {w}\xleftarrow [1_{w}]{} \bar {y}_{w}\xrightarrow [m]{} \bar {x}\right \}\mathclose {}} in which the left-hand leg is vertical and the right-hand leg is cartesian over {w}\xrightarrow {{m}}{x}. But the left-hand span {\mathopen {}\left \{\bar {w}\xleftarrow [1_{w}]{}\bar {y}_{w}\to \bar {y}_{x}\cong \bar {x}\right \}\mathclose {}} in the diagram above is exactly what we need.
We leave the converse to the reader.

fr:title.text: Cartesian lifts in the opposite category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian lifts in the opposite category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The foregoing characterization of cartesian maps in E^{\mathsf {op}} immediately implies that E^{\mathsf {op}} is fibered over B.
The displayed category E^{\mathsf {op}} is a cartesian fibration.

Fixing \bar {y}\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{y} and f:x\to y\in B, we must exhibit a cartesian lift \bar {f} : \bar {x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y}\in E^{\mathsf {op}}. By the characterization it suffices to find any map over f whose vertical component is an isomorphism. Writing \bar {y}_{x}\xrightarrow [f]{}\bar {y} for the cartesian lift of f in E, consider the map in E^{\mathsf {op}} presented by the following span in E:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <l/>{ nw = \bar {y}_{x}, ne = \bar {y}_{x}, sw = x, se = x, north/style = double, south/style = double, west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, ne/style = pullback, height = 1.5cm, } \SpliceDiagramSquare <r/>{ glue = west, glue target = l/, height = 1.5cm, east/style = lies over, ne = \bar {y}, se = y, south = f, } \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The construction of fibered opposite categories does appear quite involved, but it can be seen to be inevitable from the perspective of the fiber categories E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x}. Indeed, let u,v\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x} and fix a vertical map h : u \to v\in E^{\mathsf {op}}_{x}; by unfolding definitions, we see that the vertical map h : u \to v is uniquely determined by a morphism v\to u\in E_{x}.

A displayed morphism u\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{} v\in E^{\mathsf {op}} is determined by a span {\mathopen {}\left \{u\leftarrow v_{x} \to v\right \}\mathclose {}}\in E where the right-hand map is cartesian over 1_{x} : x\to x and the left-hand map is vertical, taken up to the identification of different cartesian lifts v_{x}\to x. A displayed morphism that is cartesian over the identity is an isomorphism; hence, displayed morphisms u\xrightarrow [1_{x}]{} v\in E^{\mathsf {op}} are equivalently determined by vertical maps v\to u \in E.

Let E be a displayed category over C; following Ahrens and Lumsdaine, we define a cleaving of E to be a function assigning to each {x}\xrightarrow {{f}}{y}\in C and u\in C_y a cartesian morphism {f^{*}u}\xrightarrow [f]{\bar {f}}{u} in E called the chosen cartesian lift of u along f.
